sentence: This case study’s objective is to describe and analyze a plausible health care setting using mHealth technology.
The analysis of the case will be based on a systematic literature review exploring the ethical concerns and problems accompanying the technology itself, the deployment, and the use of the technology.
The analysis of the case will be based on a systematic literature review exploring the ethical concerns and problems accompanying the technology itself, the deployment, and the use of the technology.

This exercise aims at giving an overview on the ethical issues relevant for the application of mHealth technology being paradigmatic for a development in health care towards more digital applications and more self-involvement of patients into their own care.
This case study focuses on one particular mHealth product as an example for mHealth technology.

A widely used definition by the WHO Global Observatory for eHealth describes mHealth as a “Medical and public health practice supported by mobile devices, such as mobile phones, patient monitoring devices, personal digital assistants (PDAs), and other wireless devices.
mHealth involves the use and capitalization on a mobile phone’s core utility of voice and short messaging service (SMS) as well as more complex functionalities.” (WHO, 2011).

Although this definition mainly focuses on the technical aspects of mHealth, meaning the intended practice or use and the technical artifacts it relies on, it will sufficiently serve the present analysis.
This use case describes a mHealth product for the monitoring of heart rhythm which consists of an ECG device and app that can be installed either on a smartphone or tablet.
Third, it makes use of the transmitters of the mobile device to process data from the ECG recorder and to share it with stakeholders via the internet.
Third, it makes use of the transmitters of the mobile device to process data from the ECG recorder and to share it with stakeholders via the internet.
Third, it makes use of the transmitters of the mobile device to process data from the ECG recorder and to share it with stakeholders via the internet.

By matching all of these criteria, this product is a valuable example for the shift in health care aiming at more self-involvement of the patient for the sake of more cost-efficiency in health care simply by digitizing services and thus promising to provide an answer to future problems for the European health care system, like our ageing population.
The description of the technology follows an ontology that sets five dimensions for mHealth: Structure, Function, Semiotics, Stakeholder, and Outcome (Figure 1).

28.2	Technology
To record an ECG the user must place two fingers of each hand on the ECG device for 30 seconds.
To record an ECG the user must place two fingers of each hand on the ECG device for 30 seconds.
The ECG device uses high frequency sound transmission to communicate the data to the app.
The ECG device uses high frequency sound transmission to communicate the data to the app.
It uses a Random Forest machine learning algorithm to analyze the ECG and to differentiate the regular sinus rhythm from Atrial Fibrillation (AF) and other rhythm disturbances.
The user can purchase the app and the ECG monitor together with a plan that provides a reviewed ECG every 90 days by a cardiologist and monthly heart health reports.
The user can purchase the app and the ECG monitor together with a plan that provides a reviewed ECG every 90 days by a cardiologist and monthly heart health reports.
The user can purchase the app and the ECG monitor together with a plan that provides a reviewed ECG every 90 days by a cardiologist and monthly heart health reports.
Both the app and the ECG device focus on the monitoring of AF which is a major risk factor for stroke and other cardiac diseases.
The product aims at increasing the likelihood of early AF diagnosis and to reduce the risk for stroke accordingly.
The product aims at increasing the likelihood of early AF diagnosis and to reduce the risk for stroke accordingly.
The app displays the ECG and notifies the user if any irregularities appear.
The app displays the ECG and notifies the user if any irregularities appear.
The patient can add information to the recording such as her name or her health insurance number.

The app synchronizes the data automatically with the company’s encrypted server where it can be accessed by health care professionals as well as relatives via a web-based application or as a report received via e-mail.
The app has been developed primarily for adult users at risk of AF to detect irregular heart rhythms.
It is primarily designed for use at home but can be used in any setting due to its portability.
Physicians can access the data to interpret any irregularities if the patient gives her consent.
Physicians can access the data to interpret any irregularities if the patient gives her consent.
The NHS funds the purchasing of the mobile ECG monitor in context of its Innovation and Technology Tariff (ITT), an initiative to promote the spread of new technical devices in the NHS.

There are two studies comparing the accuracy of the AliveCor ECG monitor with a 12-lead  ECG interpreted by a cardiologist detecting AF which is the standard in traditional care facilities like clinics and hospitals.

There are two studies comparing the accuracy of the AliveCor ECG monitor with a 12-lead  ECG interpreted by a cardiologist detecting AF which is the standard in traditional care facilities like clinics and hospitals.
The studies show that the AliveCor ECG monitor has high diagnostic accuracy for AF screening (Lau et al.
2013) and can be used for large scale screenings (Haberman et al.
Furthermore, it can be a useful tool to monitor patients after a cardiac ablation (Tarakji et al.
The ECG monitor costs €199,00, the app is free of charge.
28.3	Context
Many different contexts of use of the AliveCor heart monitor are possible.
Many different contexts of use of the AliveCor heart monitor are possible.
To illustrate the use intended by the developer the following story can be sketched out, in a seemingly typical care setting.
P checks her ECG once a week to see whether her heart rhythm shows any irregularities.
Patient P belongs to a demographic group with risk of AF.

She purchases the KardiaMobile heart monitor and uses it together with the offered plan that provides her with an ECG interpreted by a cardiologist every 90 days and a monthly report about her heart health.
Patient P belongs to a demographic group with risk of AF.
Patient P belongs to a demographic group with risk of AF.

She purchases the KardiaMobile heart monitor and uses it together with the offered plan that provides her with an ECG interpreted by a cardiologist every 90 days and a monthly report about her heart health.
Furthermore, she decides to share her ECG automatically with her sister and her practitioner.
The sister as well as the practitioner can access the data via a web-based browser application.
The patient manages the ECG data herself while she can decide for herself how and with whom she wants to share it.
The case study on the AliveCor KardioMobile app shows how the management of personal data leads to new ways of processing the data and allows for new uses of the data.
The patient manages the ECG data herself while she can decide for herself how and with whom she wants to share it.

The patient manages the ECG data herself while she can decide for herself how and with whom she wants to share it.

At the same time, the KardiaMobile app allows for additional purposes of the data that go beyond monitoring of the heart rhythm for the purpose of prevention or aftercare like in a traditional care setting due to the portability of the device and the real-time analysis of the data.

While in a traditional setting, like a clinic or hospital, a comparingly detailed ECG has primarily medical purpose and is otherwise not accessible to the patient, the mHealth product allows for additional purposes and uses in other contexts, such as for knowledge acquisition.

This is also possible due to the wide accessibility of the product and the easy manner of use.

For all three activities the data from mHealth products is immensely valuable because mHealth products offer the opportunity to gain insight on the user’s health parameters in such detail never available before while being streamed often in real-time and in every imaginable life situation.

The, focus is on the question whether it can be ethically justified to use data from mHealth products for public health purposes.

Since mHealth offers vast opportunities to exploit new markets, private companies such as Fitbit or Verily play a major role for the deployment of this technology while at the same time offering services for the storage and analysis of the respective datasets.
The collection of this data has several conditions.
First, the mHealth products as well as the according servers and data infrastructure need to be provided.

Since mHealth offers vast opportunities to exploit new markets, private companies such as Fitbit or Verily play a major role for the deployment of this technology while at the same time offering services for the storage and analysis of the respective datasets.
The second condition is the reliable use of mHealth products by the users.
Users need to be motivated to enter their data, track their fitness activities, or measure their heart rhythm.
And stakeholders such as health care providers offer incentives for the use of such products.

Since private companies own the biggest share of medical data and offer the competency for making use of this data public health institutions as well as research facilities need to rely on the cooperation with private companies if they want to make use of this data for their own interest or mission.

From the privacy policy of AliveCor it is evident that the data collected by the app is made available for various stakeholders like companies specialized in online advertising or research facilities, may they be private or public.

From the privacy policy of AliveCor it is evident that the data collected by the app is made available for various stakeholders like companies specialized in online advertising or research facilities, may they be private or public.

It also gives insight into how patients are getting more and more involved into their own care which indicates a shift of responsibility highly profitable for private companies on the one hand, and promises a benefit for public health on the other hand.
28.4.1	Analysis and Findings

The findings of the literature review encompass a discussion on empowerment and autonomy, on social inequalities, regulating mHealth, as well as research based on mHealth data, and finally privacy and trust.

The findings of the literature review encompass a discussion on empowerment and autonomy, on social inequalities, regulating mHealth, as well as research based on mHealth data, and finally privacy and trust.
This is especially relevant for an ethical evaluation focusing on the distribution of responsibility leading to increasing involvement of the patient into her own care.
Empowerment and Autonomy
The discussion on empowerment focuses on the evaluation of mHealth from the perspective of autonomy.
Is mHealth increasing autonomy for its users or does it impose a medical regime on them built on the afore mentioned normativities?

The conceptual component discusses whether empowerment provides the right frame for the debate and whether it should be replaced by concepts like engagement (Burr & Morley, 2020) or companionship (Morley & Floridi, 2019) to meaningfully approach the ethical analysis of mHealth in regards to autonomy.

The conceptual component discusses whether empowerment provides the right frame for the debate and whether it should be replaced by concepts like engagement (Burr & Morley, 2020) or companionship (Morley & Floridi, 2019) to meaningfully approach the ethical analysis of mHealth in regards to autonomy.

The way autonomy is used in this debate often confuses the different levels on which it should be addressed; a meaningful framework for the ethical evaluation of mHealth should be sensitive to the objection that autonomy must be conceptualized differently according to the ethical issues the evaluation puts into focus (Schmietow & Marckmann, 2019).

The conceptual component discusses whether empowerment provides the right frame for the debate and whether it should be replaced by concepts like engagement (Burr & Morley, 2020) or companionship (Morley & Floridi, 2019) to meaningfully approach the ethical analysis of mHealth in regards to autonomy.

Linked to this, mHealth offers an opportunity to discuss how agency and patiency can go together since patiency in mHealth can enhance a person’s agency and therefore empower the patient (Wagner, 2019).
This might be true if a user decides to quit smoking and uses an app which nudges her to change her behavior accordingly.
Empirical research shows that most mHealth products only focus on partial dimensions of engagement due to the heterogeneity of the technology (Barello et al., 2015).
This surely influences how empowered a patient can be because it determines the opportunities for the patient to act regarding her own health.
This surely influences how empowered a patient can be because it determines the opportunities for the patient to act regarding her own health.
mHealth and eHealth in general often promise to mitigate social inequalities because more people might gain access to health services.

Although this might be true in some instances, a digital divide between those who have access to the technical infrastructure; the internet and according devices to use it; is present in most societies.

Although this might be true in some instances, a digital divide between those who have access to the technical infrastructure; the internet and according devices to use it; is present in most societies.

This digital divide consists not only in inequalities in terms of internet access but also access to a broadband connection which has to be overcome in order to promote digital inclusion (Baur, 2008).

This digital divide is especially present during a public health crisis like the COVID-19 pandemic where socially disadvantaged not only suffer from worse health but are also less likely to have access to eHealth services (Khilnani et al.

Empirical evidence on intervention generated inequalities around access, targeting, personal resources or incentives, shows that self-monitoring applications are morally acceptable and that inequalities can be avoided by using specific design methods (Paldan et al., 2018).
For a long time, the FDA has followed a hands-off policy to promote innovation in the mHealth domain.
Regulation of mHealth often focuses on consumer protection.

The consumer-protection perspective also informs the ethical discussion on problems around the commercial use of health data from eHealth applications regarding direct-to-consumer advertising and the sale of medical products (Liang et al., 2011).

The consumer-protection perspective also informs the ethical discussion on problems around the commercial use of health data from eHealth applications regarding direct-to-consumer advertising and the sale of medical products (Liang et al., 2011).
Further attention has been payed to regulatory and ethical issues around technology-centered healthcare for elderly (Thompson et al., 2012).
The protection of privacy in mHealth based research needs to be balanced against possible innovations that can be highly beneficial for society (Tovino, 2020).
Social inequalities not only depend on access.
This may lead to discrimination and biased research outcomes (Callier & Fullerton, 2020).

Creating personas of different users can help determine whether research outcomes are, in fact, biased and whether enough attention has been payed to those who do not have access to mHealth products (Doerr & Guerrini, 2020).
Much more attention must be payed to mHealth research from the side of policy makers (Lang et al., 2020) as well as additional stakeholders (Hammack-Aviran et al., 2020).
Bottom-up citizen science seems to go hand in hand with the ethos of mHealth for which the Quantified Self movement provides an interesting example.
The benefit of such an approach, however, depends a lot on the participation of individuals for whom mHealth promises empowerment and autonomy.
The benefit of such an approach, however, depends a lot on the participation of individuals for whom mHealth promises empowerment and autonomy.
Privacy infringements are a major concern in the discussion on mHealth.
This is, however, not always easy since users need to be able to determine whether they can trust the design of a product to protect their privacy.

This sparks a discussion on how to provide the right evidence for the trustworthiness of such patient-computer interfaces, especially when informed consent is the chosen tool for protecting sensitive medical data (Nickel, 2011).
For users it is important to set certain requirements for data protection and to design products in ways adapted to these requirements (Milutinovic & De Decker, 2016).

Social networks raise an array of new concerns for the privacy of patients and doctors since many mHealth products offer the possibility to either share medical data online or to rate doctors on respective platforms.
